comments.content: I concur, given answer is incorrect. The RejectThreshold will drop the message, not deliver to junk.

discussion.content:
Requirement: Ensure that if an email message has a spam confidence level (SCL) of 3 or higher, the message automatically moves to the Junk Email folder.

Solution:
Set-OrganizationConfig 
-SetJunkThreshold
"You use the SCLJunkThreshold parameter Set-OrganizationConfig cmdlet to set the SCL Junk Email folder threshold value for all mailboxes in the organization. This is the only SCL threshold that you can configure at the organization level. The SCL value is typically assigned to messages by the Content Filter agent."

Correct answer is "Set-OrganizationConfig" with the "-SCLJunkThreshold" parameter:
"The SCLJunkThreshold parameter specifies the spam confidence level (SCL) threshold. Messages with an SCL greater than the value that you specify for the SCLJunkThreshold parameter are moved to the Junk Email folder. Valid values are integers from 0 through 9, inclusive."

https://docs.microsoft.com/it-it/powershell/module/exchange/set-organizationconfig?view=exchange-ps

This question is broken by the number 3 at the end.
SCLJunkThreshold set to 3 will act on SCL values greater than 3. So from 4 onwards.
"Messages with an SCL GREATER than the value that you specify for the SCLJunkThreshold"
So either technical requirements should say SCL higher than 2 or the answer should have number 4 at the end.

It wants you to: Ensure that if an email message has a spam confidence level (SCL) of 3 or higher, the message automatically moves to the Junk Email folder.

Therefore the answer would be: 
Set-OrganisationConfig
-SCLJunkThreshold
Correcto~
Set-ContentFilterConfig will only change setting for one exchange server where it is ran. We have to use Organization settings cmdlet.

3/24/2022 - on the exam
I chose:
Set-OrganizationConfig
-SCLJunkThreshold

Answer is:
Set-OrganizationConfig 
-SCLJunkThreshold

This is the only SCL threshold that you can configure at the organization level. A message with an SCL value that's greater than this value is moved to the Junk Email folder
exam dated 26-jan-22

Correcto - 
-Set-OrganizationConfig 
-SetJunkThreshold

questions.question_text:
You need to identify which users clicked the links in the phishing emails.
What should you do?

discussion.content: gz to everyone who survived so far :)

comments.content: yes, this dump has no end ^_^

discussion.content: Given answer is correct, as per MS doc: Safe Links is a feature in Microsoft Defender for Office 365 that checks links in email messages to see if they lead to malicious web sites. When a user clicks a link in a message, the URL is temporarily rewritten and checked against a list of known, malicious web sites. Safe Links includes the URL trace reporting feature to help determine who has clicked through to a malicious web site.
Correct

Selected Answer: C
Use the URL trace reporting feature.
on exam - 12/19/22

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
How many default policy tags (DPTs), retention policy tags (RPTs), and personal tags should you create to meet the retention requirements? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: Right answer is dpd-2 , rpd-2 , pt-3
on exam 27/3/23
on exam - 12/19/22

2 dpt
2 rpt
3 personal

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: 1 -
Default Policy Tags apply to any item that doesn't have another tag applied to it. We need one to meet the following requirement:
✑ Ensure that any items without a retention tag are moved to the Archive mailbox two years after they were created and permanently deleted seven years after they were created.

Box 2: 2 -
Retention Policy Tags apply to default mailbox folders (Inbox, Sent Items etc). We need two to meet the following requirements:
✑ Automatically delete items in the Junk Email folder after 30 days.
✑ Automatically delete items in the Sent Items folder after 300 days.

Box 3: 3 -
Personal tags can be applied by users to custom folders or individual emails. We need three to meet the following requirements:
✑ Enable users to tag items for deletion after one year.
✑ Enable users to tag items for deletion after two years.
✑ Enable users to tag items to be archived after one year.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/security-and-compliance/messaging-records-management/retention-tags-and-policies

questions.question_text:
You recently migrated all the on-premises mailboxes from Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 to Exchange Online.
You decommission the on-premises Exchange Server 2019 servers.
The finance department at your company reports that email delivery from several printers fails after Exchange Server 2019 is decommissioned.
You need to ensure that the printers can deliver email successfully to the users in the finance department.
What should you do?

choices.D: Create an Office 365 group for each printer.
choices.A: Create a resource mailbox for each printer.
choices.B: Create an Inbound connector that has certificate validation disabled.
choices.C: Create an Inbound connector that is configured to allow SMTP relay.

discussion.content: Any anonymous applications, or appliance that needs to be able to send mail requires an SMTP relay, given answer is correct.
C is correct
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
Answer C is in essence the least evil, aka you come to it by principle of exclusion of the other answers: D is completely out of topic; A is wrong because you need a licensed mailbox for SMTP AUTH; B is simply wrongly formulated - you need to configure the inbound connector based on IP addresses.
And no, C is NOT the "Direct Send" option. Believe me, Direct Send would be the best answer here (satisfies the requirement to send to Finance, aka internal users only), but alas it is not available. C is actually the "SMTP relay" option from this documentation: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/mail-flow-best-practices/how-to-set-up-a-multifunction-device-or-application-to-send-email-using-microsoft-365-or-office-365
yes, C is correct.

The finance department at your company reports that email delivery from several printers fails after Exchange Server 2019 is decommissioned.
You need to ensure that the printers can deliver email successfully to the users in the finance department.

Based on what question asks you can go with B or C (YES, B is LESS secure, but still..).

Selected Answer: C
It's also called, by Microsoft, as a "Direct Send".

Selected Answer: C
C is correct.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/mail-flow-best-practices/how-to-set-up-a-multifunction-device-or-application-to-send-email-using-microsoft-365-or-office-365#option-3-configure-a-connector-to-send-mail-using-microsoft-365-or-office-365-smtp-relay

The MemberJoinRestriction parameter specifies the restrictions that you put on requests to join the group. Valid values are:

Open: Users can add themselves to the group without approval from a group owner. You can't use this value on universal security groups.
Closed: Users can't add themselves to the group, and requests to join the group are rejected automatically. Group membership is controlled by the group owners. This is the default value on universal security groups and universal distribution groups.
ApprovalRequired: Users can request to join the group. The user is added to the group after the request is approved by one of the group owners. Although you can use this value on universal security groups, user requests to join the group aren't sent to the group owners, so this setting is only effective on universal distribution groups.
Actually, i believe Exchange Admin also could remove the membership
Correct
3/24/2022 - on the exam
exam dated 26-jan-22
exchange adm can manage membership of any group
